text: so I have a question for you guys what
motivates you to travel for some people
its food for others its nature or
architecture or whatever but for me it's
always been about the people I'm simply
addicted to traveling to faraway places
and connecting with local indigenous
cultures
I'm fascinated by the way these people
live and the way they maintain
historical and cultural ties with their
land I'm intrigued by how they've
survived invasion and colonization while
still holding on to their values
generation after generation the
following are five incredible indigenous
cultures I've met around the world one
the Himba tribe of Namibia a few years
ago I took a bus out into the middle of
nowhere in northern Namibia and stumbled
upon people living in tents they are
known for their unique hairstyles and
use of red clay to protect their body
from the Sun oh man this is culture we
spent about four hours together dancing
their traditional dance and observing
each other's way of life to the longneck
ladies of Thailand originating in
Myanmar the cayenne tribe came to
northern Thailand as refugees and they
carry on this custom to lengthen their
necks with brass rings as a sign of
beauty and cultural identity does it
hurt have pain no pain it's really one
of the most fascinating displays of
local culture anywhere in the world 3
the Omo Valley of Ethiopia and the
southwestern part of Ethiopia lives one
of the world's most remote tribes called
the Mercy's they are 100% nomadic people
who were unique clothes piercer inner
lips as a fashion statement well it's
pretty heavy and rely on cattle goats
and sheep to survive this is where they
keep all the goats and yes they mostly
eat them raw for the dancing tribe of
Yemen in the hot remote region of
Central Yemen there are various tribes
living in the desert and valleys of Wadi
Dohan a few weeks ago I was lucky enough
to stumble upon a wedding ceremony hello
mother go where they carried out the
most unique dances and songs it was a
very special experience 5 the new
boonies of Swaziland
[Music]
three quarters of the population of
Swaziland are the mamuni tribe and their
clans are controlled by Chiefs in my
case I was lucky to witness a female
chief who took over right after her
husband passed away I joined them for an
afternoon of traditional dances and
ceremonies and it was a day I'll never
forget so you guys might be wondering
well if these tribes are cool but why
should you care about indigenous people
well for one they protect our
environment while they only use up a
quarter of the world surface area they
shield 80 percent of Earth's
biodiversity including the force in the
Amazon the Congo and Indonesia also it's
important to acknowledge and protect
indigenous people because they're
beautiful cultures are being threatened
by our quickly globalized world I think
we can all agree that the earth is our
treasure and we need to protect our
environments and local cultures before
it's too late
I'm drew pinsky and if you like my
travel videos please click Subscribe and
join me as I plan to visit every country
in the world
